channel.description: Mangala Shri Bhuti is pleased to announce weekly teachings by web conference by Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, Jampal Norbu Namgyel, Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, and senior students of Mangala Shri Bhuti.

item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche from Samten Ling, 16 May 1999, Personal Link #42

item.title: The Link Legacy Series: A Strong Case Against Attachment
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche from Osel Ling, 2 March 2003, Personal Link #171
item.itunes:summary: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche 'makes a case' against attachment, emphasizing how logic and reason can be a force for change in working with our habits.

item.title: The Link Legacy Series: Dynamics of Insecurity, Two Kinds of Merit
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche from Osel Ling, 11 March 2001, Personal Link #96
item.itunes:summary: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche adresses how merit, especially the merit to mature, relates to our ability to overcome a pervasive suffering, that of insecurity.
item.itunes:keywords: dzigar kongtrul rinpoche, personal link, mangala shri bhuti

item.title: The Link Legacy Series: Dancing with Habits and Fears
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche from New York City, 7 May 200, Personal Link #72
item.itunes:summary: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche suggests we needn't automatically feel doomed under the power of our habits. We need to approach them with a sense of relaxation - not giving them too much power by fearing them - and learning to 'dance' with their enegery.
item.itunes:keywords: dzigar kongtrul rinpoche, personal link, mangala shri bhuti

item.title: The Link #44: Mangala Shri Bhuti's Mission: Service and Meditation
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Rinpoche's LINK from Berkeley, CA.
item.itunes:summary: Rinpoche restates the mission of Mangala Shri Bhuti: a life of service and of deepening one's nature of mind practice as a naljor.

item.title: The Link Legacy Series: Elegance and Grace
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche from Samten Ling, May 14, 2000, Personal Link #73.
item.itunes:summary: "Many people feel they were born clumsy and will die clumsy", Rinpoche says. But the relaxation that comes through practice gives rise to a natural elegance and grace.

item.title: The Link #45: Exploring Absolute Bodhicitta
item.itunes:author: Dungse Jampal Norbu
item.itunes:subtitle: Dungse Jampal Norbu from Phuntsok Choling.
item.itunes:summary: Dungse Jampal Norbu explores some of the misconceptions one may naturally have about emptiness and its relation to relative experience.

item.title: The Link #46: Emic, Edic and Faith
item.itunes:author: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel
item.itunes:subtitle: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel from Osel Ling, Crestone, CO.
item.itunes:summary: Elizabeth discusses another angle on our experience of faith

item.title: Gifts of Silence (Link #47)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche from Bir, India
item.itunes:summary: Rinpoche speaks on the power of keeping silent to bring our mental patterns into light and make our choice to 'drop it' and turn our focus to impermanence and appreciation of simplicity.

item.title: Is it Karma or Fate? (Link #48)
item.itunes:author: Dungse Jampal Norbu Namgyel
item.itunes:subtitle: Dungse Jampal Norbu Namgyel from Bir, India
item.itunes:summary: Dungse Jampal explores karma in this eloquent and insightful talk. By identifying two types of karma, personal and general (general meaning phenomena like gravity), we can address what in our karma we can do something about through practice and the view. The Q and A contains engaging discussion of topics such as fate.

item.title: "Something too important to forget." (Link #49)
item.itunes:author: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel
item.itunes:subtitle: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel from Crestone, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel comments on the poem, "The Art of Disappearing", by Naomi Shahib Nye. Renunciation expresses our deeper focus ("something too important to forget") rather than a loss of things desireable.
item.itunes:keywords: elizabeth mattis namgyel, renunciation, naomi shahib nye

item.title: Exploring the FourImmeasurables Practice (Link #50)
item.itunes:author: Khenchung Bob Reid
item.itunes:subtitle: Khenchung Bob Reid from Osel Ling, Crestone, CO.
item.itunes:summary: Note: This recording begins a few minutes into the talk and has some glitches, but recovers quickly. Bob Reid looks at the practice of regarding one's friends and enemies equally, as discussed in Khenpo Ngawang Pelang's "A Guide to the Words of My Perfect Teacher".
item.itunes:keywords: Bob Reid, Four Immeasurables, Words of My Perfect Teacher

item.title: In the Blink of An Eye(Link #51)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche from Guna Institute, Bir, India.
item.itunes:summary: Kongtrul Rinpoche reminds us how fast time passes, from a day to a month, a yearâ€”and then our entire life. What will we have made of this precious opportunity? How do we determine what is important, and not? Will we talk in the footsteps of those who have made communicating the dharma to others their priority?.

item.title: Karma and Responsibility (Link #52)
item.itunes:author: Dungse Jampal Norbu
item.itunes:subtitle: Dungse Jampal Norbu from Guna Institute, Bir, India.
item.itunes:summary: Dungse Jampal Norbu continues his exploration of karma. While dieties and our teachers 'supplement' our path, we each must clarify how our intention informs our actions as we seek to walk toward awakening.

item.title: What Drives us? (Link #53)
item.itunes:author: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel
item.itunes:subtitle: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel from Osel Ling, Crestone, CO.
item.itunes:summary: Elizabeth suggests that we need to examine where our mind is coming from when we feel driven. Is it tight, fearful and contracted? Is there something inside that is unsettled? That discomfort is often then projected to the outside world. If we stop, look at our minds and relax with the discomfort, we might find things are not what we think. Things can shift very quickly. Loneliness can change into fullness, fixation can change into openness.

item.title: What motivates us to practice? (Link #54)
item.itunes:author: Joseph Waxman
item.itunes:subtitle: Joseph Waxman from Boston, MA
item.itunes:summary: Joey Waxman, one of Mangala Shri Bhuti's khenchungs, examines his own motivation for practice, and asks the question, "how do you develop disciplne without being hard on yourself", in this personal and honest link

item.title: Welcoming the New Year: Clarity about the Past and Intention for the Future (Link #55)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, from Guna Institute, Bir, India
item.itunes:summary: New Year is a good time to review the past year to evaluate what has worked for us and what has not, what has been beneficial to others and what has not. Since we are human and not perfect, we are subject to errors and confusions. But these can be remedied. If we contemplate our mistakes with joy and without guilt, if we face our errors in judgment with courage and learn from our mistakes, we can have a clear conscience
item.itunes:keywords: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, New Year's Resolutions, Clean conscience

item.title: How to Accomplish a New Year's Resolution (Link #56)
item.itunes:author: Dungse Jampal Norbu
item.itunes:subtitle: Dungse Jampal Norbu, from Guna Institute, Bir, India
item.itunes:summary: The beginning of the new year is a time when people often make resolutions to change. They might want to quit a bad habit such as smoking or excessive drinking, or to cultivate something such as healthy eating in order to lose weight. But often these good intentions fall by the wayside and are never carried out. In order to actually accomplish one's intention, one needs in addition to intention, a vision.
item.itunes:keywords: Dungse Jampal Norbu, New Year's Resolutions

item.title: Commentary on "Looking into the World", a poem by Chogyam Trungpa Rinpoche (Link #57)
item.itunes:author: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel
item.itunes:subtitle: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, from Osel Ling, Crestone, CO
item.itunes:summary: What does Trungpa, Rinpoche mean by "don't trust"? He is not addressing things that are conventionally untrustworthy such as drug dealers, used car salesmen or large corporations. He is talking about the world always changing and not behaving according to our preferences.
item.itunes:keywords: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, Chogyam Trungpa Rinpoche, Trust

item.title: A Short Personal History (Link #58)
item.itunes:author: Rebecca Zepp
item.itunes:subtitle: Rebecca Zepp, from Phuntsok Choling, Boulder, CO
item.itunes:summary: Rebecca recounts how she entered the Buddhist path and her experience as a student of Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche over the last 20 years.

item.title: Opening the Door to Emptiness (Link #59)
item.itunes:author: Ani Pema Chodron
item.itunes:subtitle: Ani Pema Chodron, from Gampo Abbey, Cape Breton, Nova Scotia
item.itunes:summary: When we hear about the emptiness things, we might visualize that emptiness is like a hologram, having form but no substance. However, nothing we think of can actually prepare us for what the real experience of emptiness is like in life. The way our conventional mind works cannot grasp it. Chogyam Trungpa, Rinpoche describes the sunyata or emptiness experience as "a state where things fade out (stet) and future possibilities have not arisen." It also can be experienced as not knowing what to do.

item.title: How to Meditate (Link #60)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, from Guna Institute, Bir, India
item.itunes:summary: The first in a series of four recordings of Rinpoche played in February, 2011, all taken from teachings he gave during the Fall/Winter semester at Guna Institute, 2010 - 2011.

item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, from Guna Institute, Bir, India
item.itunes:summary: The second in a series of four recordings of Rinpoche played in February, 2011, all taken from teachings he gave during the Fall/Winter semester at Guna Institute, 2010 - 2011.

item.title: The Purpose of Generating Bodhicitta (Link #62)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, from Guna Institute, Bir, India
item.itunes:summary: The third in a series of four recordings of Rinpoche played in February, 2011, all taken from teachings he gave during the Fall/Winter semester at Guna Institute, 2010 - 2011.

item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, from Guna Institute, Bir, India

item.title: 2011 Losar Address (Link #64)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, from Crestone, CO.
item.itunes:summary: 2011 Losar Address.

item.title: Small Self, Large Self (Link #65)
item.itunes:author: Dungse Jampal Norbu
item.itunes:subtitle: Dungse Jampal Norbu, from Bodghaya, India
item.itunes:summary: Expanding the view beyond the self and the resultant relief from the suffering of the five negative emotions and the concept of "Small Self, Large Self".
item.itunes:keywords: Dungse Jampal Norbu, Small Self, Large Self

item.title: Bearing Witness (Link #66)
item.itunes:author: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel
item.itunes:subtitle: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, from Vero Beach, Florida
item.itunes:summary: In this talk Elizabeth discusses how to not close down around either beauty or suffering. She describes bearing witness as the inner practice of the Bodhisattva where as one serves one awakens and moves toward connectedness and interdependence.

item.title: Shoot the Hostage: The Wisdom of Letting Go May at First Seem Counterintuitive (Link #67)
item.itunes:author: Scott Gallagher
item.itunes:subtitle: Scott Gallagher, from Osel Ling, Crestone, CO
item.itunes:summary: Scott describes the impact Kongtrul Rinpoche's introduction to the way ego mind works has on our mind. With that knowledge, when strong clinging to the self comes about, we know what to do, though letting go at first may seem counterintuitive to the whole process ego sets up. So we must 'shoot the hostage'... Listen to find out more.

item.title: A Moment of Pure Sympathetic Joy: The Cricket World Cup and The Power of Mind to Bring Happiness (Link #68)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, from India
item.itunes:summary: Rinpoche reflects on how the Cricket World Cup united one billion people of all classes, colors and ages in a moment of pure joy. He contemplated how we could cultivate this same sympathetic joy in our daily lives towards even the smallest act of savings a bug and the power of our mind to bring about real happiness and contentment in this way, despite our external conditions.
item.itunes:keywords: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, A Moment of Pure Joy

item.title: Reflections on Faith (Link #69)
item.itunes:author: Dungse Jampal Norbu
item.itunes:subtitle: Dungse Jampal Norbu, from Bir, India
item.itunes:summary: Dungse-la reflects on the power of faith and gives suggestions on how to cultivate faith.
item.itunes:keywords: Dungse Jampal Norbu, Reflections on Faith

item.title: Determined Focus (Link #70)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, from Bir, India
item.itunes:summary: Rinpoche invesigates the five strengths.

item.title: Letting Go Leads to Liberation (Link #71)
item.itunes:author: Natasha Carter
item.itunes:subtitle: Natasha Carter, from Crestone, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Natasha discusses challenges faced in retreat.

item.title: Starstruck- A Dubious State (Link #72)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, from Bir, India
item.itunes:summary: Rinpoche describes how to skillfully use the power of inspiration that comes from being "starstruck" and gives clear examples of how to, and how not to follow through with that inspriration.

item.title: The Essence of Mother's Day (Link #73)
item.itunes:author: Dungse Jampal Norbu
item.itunes:subtitle: Dungse Jampal Norbu, from Bir, India
item.itunes:summary: Jampal contemplates materialistic mind in the modern world and discusses the remedy to the mistaken belief that "things bring happiness".
item.itunes:keywords: Dungse Jampal Norbu, The Essence of Mother's Day

item.title: The Propensity To be Bothered (Link #74)
item.itunes:author: Ani Pema Chodron
item.itunes:subtitle: Ani Pema Chodron, from Pema Osel, Vershire, Vermont
item.itunes:summary: Ani Pema provides a commentary on the Lojong slogan, "Drive All Blames Into One", and gives us tips on distinguishing between what causes our suffering and what triggers it.
item.itunes:keywords: Ani Pema Chodron, The Propensity To Be Bothered

item.title: Certainty (Link #75)
item.itunes:author: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel
item.itunes:subtitle: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, from Crestone, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: How do we develop a certainty that is not static or about being a 'knower'? Elizabeth delves into the question of having confidence in an uncertain world and upon what that confidence is based.

item.title: Exertion: Honoring our Buddha Nature (Link #76)
item.itunes:author: Sasha Dorje Meyerowitz
item.itunes:subtitle: Sasha Dorje Meyerowitz, from Crestone, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Exertion: honoring our Buddha nature. Sasha explores how to experience exertion as a natural expression of our Buddha nature.
item.itunes:keywords: Sasha Dorje Meyerowitz, Exertion: Honoring Our Buddha Nature

item.title: Five Steps to Handle Chaos (Link #77)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:summary: Five Steps to Handle Chaos. Rinpoche explains five steps to skillfully handle situations when chaos arises in our lives, talks about the practice of acceptance and harvesting the pain of failure to gain success.
item.itunes:keywords: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, Five Steps to Handle Chaos

item.title: Maintaining Awareness as a Bodhicitta Practice (Link #78)
item.itunes:author: Dungse Jampal Norbu
item.itunes:subtitle: Dungse Jampal Norbu, from Bir, India
item.itunes:summary: Dungse-la observes that in our fast paced modern world, awareness often gets "stretched thin." Without awareness, there's more of a chance that the five negative emotions will slip in and overtake our mind. So putting an emphasis on maintaining awareness as a bodhcitta practice bridges the gap between meditation and post meditation practice, allowing us to carry out working with the paramitas to counter the negative emotions in our daily lives, even with the speed of modernity.

item.title: Letting Go Into Humbleness (Link #79)
item.itunes:author: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel
item.itunes:subtitle: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, from Crestone, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Elizabeth shares her personal experiences in relating with her teacher and describes the skillful means and "practice" in this relationship. Elizabeth describes what it means to be a student and the discipline of falling apart and letting go into humbleness.

item.title: What Is Happiness? (Link #80)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche Legacy Series, From Guna Institute, Bir, India, May 16, 2011.
item.itunes:summary: Rinpoche talks about the necessity of some suffering in developing a happy and cheerful mind that has stability. He goes on to discuss how to experience growth.
item.itunes:keywords: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, What Is Happiness?

item.title: Organized Mind (Link #81)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche Legacy Series, from Guna Institute, Bir, India, April 18, 2011
item.itunes:summary: Rinpoche discusses the tendency for humans to feel the "privilege"of self-pity and contrasts this with the qualities of a mature mind. Rinpoche explores the differences of feeling burdened by the sufferings of samsara versus feeling encouraged to find a solution.

item.title: The Affliction of Timuk (Link #82)
item.itunes:author: Dungse Jampal Norbu
item.itunes:subtitle: Dungse Jampal Norbu, from Phuntsok Choling, Ward, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Dungse-la speaks about Timuk- "a dull flat state of disconnectedness" and outlines various remedies including mindfulness, a keen awareness of one's environment and how the practice of the four noble truths brings us back.
item.itunes:keywords: Dungse Jampal Norbu, The Affliction of Timuk

item.title: Exploring Beliefs (Link #83)
item.itunes:author: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel
item.itunes:subtitle: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, from Crestone Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Elizabeth explores the many usages of the word "belief", how we experience beliefs and belief as it relates to the Buddha's teachings on emptiness and the Middle Way. Talk given from Crestone, Colorado.

item.title: Awakening In The Charnel Ground (Link #84)
item.itunes:author: Ani Pema Chodron
item.itunes:subtitle: Ani Pema Chodron, from Osel Ling, Crestone Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Pema explains how the hardest of circumstances can be the greatest opportunity for awakening. She offers steps toward staying "awake and open" to the intensity and describes how emotions become a catalyst for emptiness or egolessness.
item.itunes:keywords: Ani Pema Chodron, Awakening In The Charnel Ground

item.title: Psychology and Buddhism (Link #85)
item.itunes:author: Gretchen Kahre-Holland
item.itunes:subtitle: Gretchen Kahre-Holland, from Phuntsok Choling, Ward, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Gretchen speaks about mind and emotions from her experience as a western and contemplative psychologist and a Buddhist practitioner. She explains how the practice of tonglen combats the two tendencies and protects from impulsivity, while holding a space for others.

item.title: Back To Our Roots (Link #86)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, from Warsaw, Poland
item.itunes:summary: Rinpoche encourages us to get back to our roots by transforming our state of mind with the four samtens, the Four Immeasurables as a daily practice, in order to have a rich internal life. He describes in detail the first two stages of bodhisattva training, generating respectful equality and universal love and care for all beings.
item.itunes:keywords: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, Back To Our Roots

item.title: The Individual and The Community (Link #87)
item.itunes:author: Dungse Jampal Norbu
item.itunes:subtitle: Dungse Jampal Norbu, from Ward, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Dungse-la discusses the necessity of having a solid "individual life" as a foundation to be of benefit to the larger community, which he defines as all sentient beings. He describes how thinking of and caring for others brings greater joy than caring for ourselves, and with repeated practice how the "illusion of duality begins to fade."
item.itunes:keywords: Dungse Jampal Norbu, The Individual and The Community

item.title: Loving Even More.....After Grief and Loss (Link #88)
item.itunes:author: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel
item.itunes:subtitle: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, from Osel Ling, Crestone, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Elizabeth describes brokenheartedness as seeing the nature of impermanence vividly, and discusses why heartbreak and loss are critical for a practitioner--how the "sting" of loss is necessary in creating an openheartedness, which is the place where practitioners need to reside. She describes how loss pushes us in the direction of a bigger way of being.
item.itunes:keywords: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, Loving Even More....After Grief and Loss

item.title: The Joy of Sadness (Link #89)
item.itunes:author: Khenchung Vern Mizner
item.itunes:subtitle: Khenchung Vern Mizner, from Crestone, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Vern contemplates why we fear sadness and describes the richness inherent in sadness--a genuine part of the human experience worth exploring in its own right. He describes the beauty and joy of sadness and why this "emotion" was held in high regard by the lineage masters.
item.itunes:keywords: Khenchung Vern Mizner, The Joy of Sadness

item.title: The Predator Mentality and Developing Bodhicitta (Link Legacy Series)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Pre-recorded talk by Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:summary: This excerpt from the 2011 Dzogchen Seminar explores what Rinpoche calls the "predator mentality", the default state of mind in samsara when you do not reflect on how yourself and all beings desire happiness equally.

item.title: How Learning Should Shape the Mind (Link Legacy Series)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Pre-recorded talk by Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche from Guna Institute.

item.title: Child of Enlightened Nature (Link Legacy Series)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Pre-recorded talk by Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche from Guna Institute.

item.title: Purifying the Small Self (Link Legacy Series)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Pre-recorded talk by Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche from the 2011 Shedra

item.title: Purifying the Small Self (Link Legacy Series)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Pre-recorded talk by Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche from the 2011 Shedra

item.title: Clinging to the Concept of Self and Other (Link #90)
item.itunes:author: Dungse Jampal Norbu
item.itunes:subtitle: Dungse Jampal Norbu, from Phuntsok Choling, Ward, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Dungse-la contemplates how building an identity around an object changes the value of our experience thereby leading to a loss of appreciation, joy and contentment for what is.
item.itunes:keywords: Dungse Jampal Norbu, Clinging to the Concept of Self and Other

item.title: Enter The Circle of Dogs (Link #91)
item.itunes:author: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel
item.itunes:subtitle: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, from Crestone, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Elizabeth explores a profound Kadampa teaching that exposes the pain experienced by the ego when grasping or clinging to one's identity, and the freedom and confidence that can arise from realizing there is no truth to identity. She explains the difference between the humility that comes from a falling away of the ego versus the "ego of low self esteem".
item.itunes:keywords: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, Enter The Circle of Dogs

item.title: Modern Day Bodhisattva (MDB) Training- Introduction (Link #92)
item.itunes:author: Khenchung Bob Reid
item.itunes:subtitle: Khenchung Bob Reid from Phuntsok Choling, Ward, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Bob explains the two objectives or guiding principles for MSB's inaugural six-week course- "Modern Day Bodhisattva (MDB) Training" beginning 11/7/11. These are (1) developing self reflection- cultivating the inner life and (2) developing a good heart-the effects of training the mind in altruism.
item.itunes:keywords: Bob Reid, Modern Day Bodhisattva (MDB) Training- Introduction

item.title: Don't Make Yourself Small- Become the Trutral" (Link #93)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, pre-recorded at 2011 Shedra, Phuntsok Choling, Ward, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Rinpoche discusses the predisposition of humans to make themselves small and reveals the truth of becoming the trutral itself.
item.itunes:keywords: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, Become The Trutral

item.title: It's Such A Nuisance To Be Attached (Link #94)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche from Phuntsok Choling, Ward, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Rinpoche discusses how attachment makes us wobbly and weaker on the path, having no solid footing and diminished self esteem. He discusses how to relate to attachment through self reflection, the courage of letting go and the power of intention.
item.itunes:keywords: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, It's Such A Nuisance To Be Attached

item.title: Bodhicitta As A Bridge (Link #95)
item.itunes:author: Dungse Jampal Norbu
item.itunes:subtitle: Dungse Jampal Norbu, Boulder, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Dungse-la underscores the importance of openness and trust as the link to the larger self, and in opening to the larger self how bodhicitta serves as both the vehicle (to enlightenment) and the bridge (counters the small self and negative habits).
item.itunes:keywords: Dungse Jampal Norbu, Bodhicitta As A Bridge

item.title: Light Comes Through-The Power of Accumulating Merit (Link #96)
item.itunes:author: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel
item.itunes:subtitle: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, Crestone, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Elizabeth explores the way to develop confidence in our basic nature as our "resting place" and how cultivating merit is the key to find the cracks in the system in order to let the light come through.
item.itunes:keywords: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, Light Comes Through, Accumulating Merit

item.title: Arrogance (Link #97)
item.itunes:author: Nicholas Carter
item.itunes:subtitle: Nicholas Carter, Crestone, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Nicholas explores arrogance.

item.title: Sustained From Within: Faith, Surrender and Acknowledgment (Link #98)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, Crestone, Colorado,(previously recorded on April 9, 2006)
item.itunes:summary: In this pre-recorded talk (4/9/2006) given at Samten Ling, Rinpoche offers three remedies for shakiness that can stem from a lack of confidence or faith in one's practice. He explains how these remedies, Faith, Surrender and Acknowledgment and the relative practice of devotion (mugu) can ultimately lead to absolute realization.
item.itunes:keywords: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, Devotion, Mugu, Faith, Surrender, Acknowledgment

item.title: Bodhicitta is in the Details (Link #99)
item.itunes:author: Dungse Jampal Norbu
item.itunes:subtitle: Dungse Jampal Norbu, Bir, India
item.itunes:summary: Dungse-la reflects on aspiration and engagement bodhicitta and its expression on a personal level in our thoughts and actions and on a larger scale within societies and cultures.
item.itunes:keywords: Dungse Jampal Norbu, Bodhicitta, Engagement, Aspiration

item.title: Merging Systems, Responding to the Suffering in the World (Link #100)
item.itunes:author: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel
item.itunes:subtitle: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, Crestone, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Elizabeth discusses our relationship with our world and the activity of awareness, especially when relating to suffering. She describes how to be in relationship with everything in our world with dynamic systems merging. "The more we include the freer we become".
item.itunes:keywords: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, Relationships, Interdependence, Emptiness, Suffering, Bearing Witness

item.title: New Year's Day Address (Link #101)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, Bir, India
item.itunes:summary: Rinpoche talks about spiritual growth for the new year and describes how to relate to the "anxiety of change" in our life.
item.itunes:keywords: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, New Year Address 2012, Relating to Change

item.title: Devotion and Distraction (Link #102)
item.itunes:author: Dungse Jampal Norbu
item.itunes:subtitle: Dungse Jampal Norbu, Bir, India
item.itunes:summary: Dungse-la discusses the key trait of devotion as being a person who pursues their purpose with single-minded focus without distraction. He uses the 2012 Kalachakra gathering in Bodhgaya as an example of devotion and describes the relationship between devotion and distraction.

item.title: Intimacy and Non-Separation (Link #103)
item.itunes:author: Chris Riggert
item.itunes:subtitle: Chris Riggert, Pema Osel Do Ngak Choling, VT
item.itunes:summary: Chris discusses how feeling of separate from others is the same as a lack of intimacy with, or feeling separate from, the Self. He describes the practice of bearing witness as an example of intimacy and non-separation, and gives examples that illustrate how we handle others is really how we handle ourselves.
item.itunes:keywords: Chris Riggert, Self Intimacy, Non-Separation, Oneness

item.title: The Future of Buddhism in the West: Looking Deep (Link #104)
item.itunes:author: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel
item.itunes:subtitle: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, Crestone, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Elizabeth shares her inquiry into what is special about the Dharma and what we want to carry forward. This led her back to the Buddha's teachings of The Middle Way and "the practice of resting in open inquiry", "looking deeply at what's timeless and placeless" and "entering the Hall of Doubt".
item.itunes:keywords: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, Buddhism in the West, Middle Way, Openness, State of Inquiry

item.title: Dunzhi and Distraction (Link #105)
item.itunes:author: Mark Smith
item.itunes:subtitle: Mark Smith, Ward, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Mark reminds us of Dunzhi, or the seemingly important "little things" that proliferate to fill our lives and take us away from the upayas given to us by our teachers, distract us from practice and take us away from fulfilling our deepest aspirations.

item.title: Transforming the Root (Link #106)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche- Legacy Series
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, pre-recorded July 2003
item.itunes:summary: This is the first in a three part series of pre-recorded talks on Chopa, a Tibetan term generally defined as "a practitioner", but more specifically defined as a practitioner who has transformed their mind by working with self-clinging.
item.itunes:keywords: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, Chopa, Transforming the Root

item.title: Strength of Intention (Link #107)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche- Legacy Series
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, pre-recorded July 2003
item.itunes:summary: This is the second in a three part series of pre-recorded talks on Chopa, a Tibetan term generally defined as "a practitioner", but more specifically defined as a practitioner who has transformed their mind by working with self-clinging.
item.itunes:keywords: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, Chopa, Strength of Intention

item.title: Staying on the Peak (Link #108)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche- Legacy Series
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, pre-recorded July 2003
item.itunes:summary: This is the third and final in a three part series of pre-recorded talks on Chopa, a Tibetan term generally defined as "a practitioner", but more specifically defined as a practitioner who has transformed their mind by working with self-clinging.
item.itunes:keywords: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, Chopa, Staying on the Peak

item.title: Losar Address- Year of the Water Dragon (Link #109)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, from Phuntsok Choling, 26 Feb, 2012
item.itunes:summary: As the new year is upon us, Rinpoche encourages us to become vigorous in taking opportunities to serve others, grow the sense of care within ourselves and in the process drop our self attachments: "Offer yourself in any way to serve others and take that as your spiritual path".

item.title: The Clear Aspect of Compassion (Link #110)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, from Bir India given on November 29, 2011, aired March 4, 2012
item.itunes:summary: Rinpoche gave this talk to students of the Guna Institute in November 2011. He describes how the "clear state of compassion" is focused internally on how we, as senient beings, suffer from self-clinging and then having the integrity to work against it.
item.itunes:keywords: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, Clear Compassion, Self-Clinging, Chopa

item.title: A Mathematical Aspiration (Link #111)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, from Bir India given on December 14, 2011, aired March 11, 2012
item.itunes:summary: Rinpoche gave this talk to students of the Guna Institute on December 14, 2011.
item.itunes:keywords: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, Mathematical Aspiration, Bir

item.title: True Renunciation (Link #112)
item.itunes:author: Dungse Jampal Norbu
item.itunes:subtitle: Dungse Jampal Norbu, from Bodhgaya, India
item.itunes:summary: Dungse-la contemplates the meaning of true renunciation of samsara while in Bodhgaya, India.

item.title: Appreciation (Link #113)
item.itunes:author: Stephanie Kindberg
item.itunes:subtitle: Stephanie Kindberg, from Bir, India
item.itunes:summary: Stephanie offers tips to generate appreciation in daily life including the importance of self-reflection, allowing space in our minds, contemplating our precious human births and impermanence.

item.title: Appreciation (Link #114)
item.itunes:author: Dungse Jampal Norbu
item.itunes:subtitle: Dungse Jampal Norbu, from Bir, India
item.itunes:summary: Inspired by the previous week's contemplations on appreciation, Dungse-la expands on the importance of appreciation throughout one's journey on the path.

item.title: Softening The Heart, Awakening The Mind (Link #115)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, a pre-recorded talk given in 2011 at Nalanda West, Seattle, Washington
item.itunes:summary: Aired a pre-recorded talk given by Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche at Nalanda West in Seattle Washington in 2011. This talk is available for purchase on the MSB Webstore for $35.
item.itunes:keywords: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, Softening The Heart, Awakening The Mind

item.title: Reflections on The Teachings (Link #116)
item.itunes:author: Andrew Shakespeare
item.itunes:subtitle: Andrew Shakespeare, from Phuntsok Choling, Ward, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Andrew recollects various teachings he has received over the years as student of Mangala Shri Bhuti, sharing with us his experiences on topics such as individual liberation, stupidity, laziness, buddha nature and aspiration bodicitta.
item.itunes:keywords: Andrew Shakespeare, Reflections, Liberation, Buddha Nature, Aspiration Bodhicitta

item.title: Sangha: Servants of Wakefulness (Link #117)
item.itunes:author: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel
item.itunes:subtitle: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, from Sarasota, Florida
item.itunes:summary: Elizabeth gives her final talk in a four-part series on taking refuge, the Buddha, Dharma and Sangha to a group of aspiring students in Florida. In this talk, Elizabeth defines Sangha as a vehicle that teaches us who we really are and serves as a support for us to find our resting place.
item.itunes:keywords: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, Sangha, Community, Interdependence

item.title: Cultivating Practice (Link #118)
item.itunes:author: Suzy Greanias
item.itunes:subtitle: Suzy Greanias, from Crestone, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Suzy talks about two levels to effectively cultivate practice: Taking the time and having a balanced approach to all levels of study and practice. She describes in detail each level and suggests in doing so, we make a "revolutionary commitment to ourselves". .
item.itunes:keywords: Suzy Greanias, Practice, Meditative Stability, Study and Practice

item.title: Creating a Simplified Life (Link #119)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, from Bir, India
item.itunes:summary: Rinpoche reminds us to make the best of our time now so we will not have any regrets at the end of our life. He describes the merit and beauty of a simplified life and instructs us on the ways to remain resilient and resolute in our commitment to practice the dharma.
item.itunes:keywords: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, Simplify, Renunciation, Distraction

item.title: Zeal in Practice (Link #120)
item.itunes:author: Dungse Jampal Norbu
item.itunes:subtitle: Dungse Jampal Norbu, from Bir, India
item.itunes:summary: Dungse-la talks about taking challenging times onto the path, yet at the same time not taking ego onto the path, say, by being hard on onesself.
item.itunes:keywords: Dungse Jampal Norbu, Zeal in Practice

item.title: The Power of Imagination (Link #121)
item.itunes:author: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel
item.itunes:subtitle: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, from Vershire, Vermont
item.itunes:summary: Elizabeth explains how imagination is used in Buddhist practice starting in the mahayana and as skillful means in the Vajrayana. Elizabeth shares stories that illustrate how thoughts are imaginary and how we can use imagination to generate bodhicitta.
item.itunes:keywords: Elizabeth Mattis Namgyel, Imagination, Thoughts, Labels

item.title: The Ego of Identity (Link #122)
item.itunes:author: Bill Roberts
item.itunes:subtitle: Bill Roberts, from Crestone, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Bill shares his personal self reflections in looking closely at how ego operates in his life.
item.itunes:keywords: Bill Roberts, Ego, Practice, Self Reflection

item.title: In Times of Uncertainty (Link #123)
item.itunes:author: Dungse Jampal Norbu
item.itunes:subtitle: Dungse Jampal Norbu, from Crestone, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Dungse-la describes the wisdom in "not knowing" when the path ahead seems unclear and underscores the importance of engaging in altruistic activities.

item.title: The Definition of a Modern Day Bodhisattva (Link #124)
item.itunes:author: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche
item.itunes:subtitle: Dzigar Kongtrul Rinpoche, from Phuntsok Choling, Ward, Colorado
item.itunes:summary: Rinpoche describes in detail how one can achieve true happiness, independent of external circumstances, by cultivating a genuinely altruistic heart.

item.title: Human- All Too Human (Link #125)
item.itunes:author: Joey Waxman
item.itunes:subtitle: Joey Waxman from Pema Osel Do Ngak Choling, Vershire, Vermont
item.itunes:summary: Joey talks about obstacles that can arise on the path, specifically feeling bad about ones self and the freedom that tolerance can bring when extending this to ourselves and others.
item.itunes:keywords: Joey Waxman, Obstacles on the Path

item.title: The Four Thoughts (Link #126)
item.itunes:author: Moni Banerjee
item.itunes:subtitle: Moni Banerjee, from Phuntsok Choling, Ward, Colorado

item.itunes:subtitle: John Clancy, Phuntsok Choling, Ward, CO

He points out how impermanence and kindness are ordinary experiences in our lives and recounts how his heart attack and stories of the people who helped him survive.

item.itunes:subtitle: Kelly Smith, Samten Ling, Crestone, CO

item.itunes:subtitle: Bill Filter, from Phuntsok Choling, Ward, CO

item.itunes:subtitle: Kate Dobbertin from Phuntsok Choling, Ward, CO

Renunciation is based upon an intelligent analysis of what will bring genuine happiness to our life and rejection is based upon ignorance and aggression.

item.itunes:subtitle: Mary Cobb from Phuntsok Choling, Ward, Colorado

item.itunes:summary: Gretchen shares several lively personal stories that illustrate how to be a student of the lineage.

item.itunes:author: MSB Student Katie Keach
